# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is the solution for this task:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”
    df_filtered = filter(row -> row[:manufacturer] == "audi" && (row[:model] == "a4" || row[:model] == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows in the filtered DataFrame
    insertcols!(df_filtered, :audi_a4_type => trues(nrow(df_filtered)))
    
    return df_filtered
end

# Test the function with example data
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])

result = audi_filter(df_cars)
println(result)
```

This code defines the `audi_filter` function as described in the task. It first filters the input DataFrame based on the manufacturer and model, then adds a new column with constant true values to the filtered DataFrame using the `insertcols!` function, and finally returns the resulting DataFrame. The function is tested with an example DataFrame `df_cars`.
